Jim,

Thank you for your reply.

Unfortunately the tsuba and fuchi are not signed. The kashira is 
lost and has been replaced with a polished horn one. The menuki are 
matching good quality shakudo with gilding, catfish and plants 
design.

The blade has been cut down by several inches, so unfortunately any 
signature it once had is gone.
A few people I have showed the sword to have commented on the 
unusual saya bevel.

I was told by a dealer that from the style of the sword it wouldn't 
have been part of a daisho. Interestingly enough it also appears to 
have battle damage on the back of the mune.

Thanks,

Peter














--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...> 
wrote:
> Peter,
> The original metal fittings appear to be a set by one maker or at 
least a single workshop.  I think that they could be work from 
Shonai in northern Honshu.  Is the fuchi or tsuba signed?  The 
kozuka is a later substitution of lower quality.  I can't really see 
the menuki in the photos.  The kashira appears to be of a different 
material.  I'm guessing that it may have been lost and that the 
tsuka has been rewrapped, but I can't see much in the photos.
> 
> The bevel on the saya would be up against the body when the sword 
was worn so it's probably not just for show.  My guess is that it 
might be more comfortable to wear or would help position it somehow 
(?).  It's an unusual feature.  Does anyone know what it's called or 
what it is really for?
> 
> As a lone wakizashi it could have been worn by a non-samurai, but 
I don't see anything about the koshirae that would make that 
necessarily so.  
> 
> Jim
